F5B3132784C44DD2A05545A655B1236B.description: Apply energy conservation in analyzing the motion of an object that is projected straigh up from a planet's surface or that is projected directly toward the planet from far above the surface.

CE34EEDC48F54219895BA0C23FCEAA5B.description: Apply angular momentum conservation and energy conservation to relate teh speeds of an object at the two extremes of an elliptical orbit.

CAF0239BFBA3440F87023E81E870149A.description: Apply conservation of angular momentum to determin the velocity and radial distance at any point in the orbit.

2A7634DF48E54789B0AF81CD15266E87.description: State Kepler's three laws of planetary motion and use them to dexcribe in qualitative terms the motion of an object in an elliptical orbit.

3789BA74CD5A41198222B9A14201C68F.description: Derive and apply the relations among kinetic energy, potential energy an total eneryg for such an orbit.

FB5D1051D7894AB0AD1E2DA72C20E988.description: Derive Kepler's third law for the case of circular orbits.

E791FE1D5C974CFDA5F9FC29B0884876.description: Recognize that the motion does not depend on the object's mass; describe qualitatively how the velocity, period of revolution and centripetal acceleration depend upon the radius of the orbit; and derive expressions for the velocity and period of revolutions in such an orbit.

71C756268D134A998E18614910CAAB36.description: Students should understand the motion of an object in orbit under the influence of gravitational forces, so they can:

175EA97348BD4234897EA51C8519C595.description: Describe the gravitational force inside and outside a uniform sphere, and calculate how the field at the surface depends on the radius and density of the sphere.

05C345901F6E41B098A5B9C5F231BD65.description: Determine the strength of the gravitational field at a specific point outside the spherer.

4DF5C347573E48F5A0F5FD967E251532.description: Determine the force that one spherically symmetrical mass exerts on another.

C0C9FE7412214A5C96A87E1643FEDA6D.description: Students should know Newton's law of universal gravitation, so they can:

2E2D5D189B744086BBF0675B97B5D730.description: Analyze the motion of a torsional pendulum or physical pendulum in order to determine the period of small oscillations.

A91B47F04B754B93A0DB49BFF403BDAD.description: State what approximation must be made in deriving the period

D43E07714E1B4B9893127C19D4C0D9EB.description: Apply the experession for the period of a simple pendulum.

2B770D90CF1F41F1B6B0563A46202B5A.description: Derive the expression for the period of a simple pendulum.

C7E28F9A977A4355875FEA51036703EC.description: Students should be able to apply their knowledge of simple harmonic motion to the case of a pendulum, so they can:

19A5526860864850B2C8E7E3922DDE76.description: Dtermine the period of oscillation for systems involving series or parallel combinations of identical springs, or springs of differening lengths.

382453B60CF540CF8475D178950EB93A.description: Analyze problems in which a mass attached to a spring oscillates horizontally.

43601933E11B4B289232A69BB91930C1.description: Analyze problems in which a mass hangs from a spring and oscillates vertically

50790674A08A475E96508D743ACCF386.description: Apply the expression for the period of oscillation of a mass on a spring.

D5F9CD426B884222AB69A7D576A399C4.description: Derive the expression for the period of oscillation of a mas on a spring.

21C38E1B9F1B4E299C6E0539F27DFB5F.description: Students should be able to apply their knowledge of simple harmonic motion to the case of a mass on a spring, so they can:

8FCEE565308941B8B65B924FAE4A1F24.description: Develop a qualitative understanding of resoncance so tehy can identify situations in which a system iwill resonate in response to a sinusoidal external force.

419DBE0A52894EB7BD5F71203208C88F.description: Calculate the maximum displacement or velocity of a particle that moves in simple harmonic motion with specified initial position and velocity.

61B5F6BFC3FF4685922FD08B2D765261.description: Calculate the kinetic and potential energies of an oscillating system as functions of time, sketch or identify graphs of these functions, and prove that the sum of kinetic and potential energy is concstant.

525C58B91982411BAF45305F07FAAB0E.description: Stat how the total eneryg of an oscillating system depend on teh amplitude of the motion, sketch or identify a graph of kinetic or potential energy as a function of time, and identify points in the motion where this energy is all potential or all kinetic.

9386B6226CF44EF0AECDF8A3202B8499.description: Recognize that a system that obeys a differential equation of the form (d^2)x/dt^2=-(ω^2)x must execute simple harmonic motion, and determine the frequency and period of such motion.

74EC9CE5D5E3483492AC6E5E5F782611.description: State and apply the relation between frequency and period.

EB953834D5164E06A659761496B6BAF5.description: State the relations between acceleration, velocity and displacement, and identify points in the motion where these quantities are zero or achieve their greatest positive and negative values.

AF2BA49B5E7643D398C14C1A212DC4E0.description: Find an expression for velocity as a function of time.

5341CC23ACA74C27A1964E98CCD49CEE.description: Write down an appropriate expression for displacement of the form A*sin(ωt) or A*cos(ωt) to describe the motion.

03A136B8F24C440787604CC013A3B001.description: Sketch or identify a graph of displacement as a function of time, and determine from such a graph the amplitude, period and frequency of the motion.

28E34B99194D4AF2AAB9E1229FB3153E.description: Students should understand simple harmonic motion, so they can:

B8A76DBAD5EF469F8D42BDFC9BDAF777.description: Simple harmonic motion (dynamics and energy relationships)

F6D7EFDA2C744114ABC898E40598BDC8.description: Analyze a collision between a moving particle and a rigid object that can rotate about a fixed axis or about its center of mass.

A3AFF35257034A088952BE16C4EB007F.description: Analyze problems in which the moemnt of inertia of an object is changed as it rotates freely about a fixed axis.

EBCB341B88B647DAA98977EC8DA904AC.description: State the relation between net external torque and angular momentum, and identify situations in which angular momentum is conserved.

A443D81C55604E2F8B8E89A1F1E247DB.description: Recognize the conditions under which the law of conservation is applicable and relate this law to one- and two-particles systems such as satellite orbits.

FC22455808AE4570A438E0FBE2DEA366.description: Students should understand angular momentum conservation, so they can:

2C16D81836094F8CBE00F506B0502280.description: Calculate the angular momentum vector for a rotating rigid object in simple cases where this vector lies parallel to the angular velocity vector.

172789ED91D44576A19FCFAA83CF694C.description: Calculate the angular momentum vector for a moving particle.

6C80B178ADFD4205AB869FE80F54BEEC.description: Calculate the torqu of a specified force about an arbitrary origin.

D9BCF7B7010847A28E632413F2EBD5F7.description: Students should be able to use the vector product and the right-hand rule, so they can:

18AD48A8802E478F940F4D9B0B134759.description: Calculate the total kinetic energy of an object that is undergoing both translational and rotational motion, and apply energy conservation in analyzing such motion.

E70562B0988E491E94E4CF61A7B6F7EC.description: Apply the equations of translational and rotational motion simultaneously in analyzing rolling with slipping.

BE0068FB032447EAB588DDD48244A4F7.description: Write down, justify and apply the relation between linear and angular velocity, or between linear and angular acceleration, for an object of circular corss-section that rolls without slipping along a fixed plane, and determine the velocity and acceleration of an arbitrary point on such an object.

0447FB48D99E444C8DC595951537FFCF.description: Students should understand the motion of a rigid object along a surface, so they can:

39DA46AD2C464B6FA4E28DF58F01D1EF.description: Analyze problems involving strings and massive pulleys.

C81DE17C6AD64B989E41CF40DDB11729.description: Apply conservation of energy to problems of fixed-axis rotation.

7CAFE4CD1C0542ADA31D21A0AFDFCAB8.description: Determine the radial and tangential acceleration of a point on a rigid object.

7DF1572A260A431785BAA933E990B80C.description: Determine the angular acceleration with which a rigid object is acceleratd about a fixed axis when subjected to a specified external towque or force.

92A2D83E82974E9AB6B5C085CFE1D512.description: Describe in detail the analogy between fixed-axis rotation and straight-line translation.

D717AF0623694B808ABA731E957AF4F6.description: Students should understand the dynamics of fixed-axis rotation, so they can:

56236DA9D3904D9EB95AA8141E944BA6.description: Students should be able to use the right-hand rule to associate an angular velocity vector with a rotating object.

080BC699F8D94201AE29573FECC21D77.description: Students should understand the analogy between translational and rotational kinematics so they can write and apply relations among the angular acceleration, angular velocity, and angular displacement of an object that rotates about a fixed axis with constant angular acceleration.

E3381D6C580C43D7AAE0A050963272A2.description: Students should be able to state and apply the parallel-axis theorem.

58193D9CD15B421698F5BCBA93AF4098.description: A thin cylindrical shell about its axis, or an object that may be viewed as being made up of coaxial shells.

874A38E023FA42A18621ACED0A70B7BB.description: A thin rod of uniform density, about an arbitrary axis perpendicular to the rod.

B2F271E316654988817FC9669F9B0825.description: A collection of point masses lying in a plane about an axis perpendicular to the plane.

1491953D208E4994AA49953693C53306.description: Students should develop skill in computing rotational inertia so they can find the rotational inertia of:

A79228495B344CB2ABC50EB7DE083ECD.description: Determine by what factor an object's rotational inertia changes if all its dimensions are increased by the same factor.

3674583DAA2C454B9E517ABBE7B26B41.description: Determine by inspection which of a set of symmetrical objects of equal mass has the greatest rotational inertia.

9A56B50BDFFF469B82066F272AA0BE00.description: Students should develop a qualitative understanding of rotational inertia, so they can:

3AB7F8A7749A410B8F2330055592544E.description: Apply these conditions in analyzing the eqilibrium of a rigid object under the combined influence of a number of coplanar forces applied at different locations.

8EE7B6B60D9D4350949031291DCAD4F1.description: State the conditions for translational and roatational equilibrium of a rigid object.

E2EF667E7D5143A08D8B0B8C979CE36E.description: Students should be able to analyze problems in statics, so they can:

E27A26A0FA5E4894A45CFE9ACB14262B.description: Calculate the torque on a rigid object due to gravity.

E83564CBC3B2414D8DF5080DD577F434.description: Calculate the magnitude and direction of the torque associated with a given force.

4C8CAA4CEA4B4EB1BD352876B2492CB7.description: Students should understand the concept of torque, so they can:

5CBF5AD180C14504ACA255CB5E62E798.description: Motion in a vertical circle (e.g., mass swinging on the end of a string, cart rolling down a curved track, rider on a Ferris wheel).

2F8CB8F96B3E4D45BD000F00D44218DB.description: Motion in a horizontal circle (e.g., mass on a rotating merry-go-round, or car rounding a banked curve).

971D8636359646F0866CAFD6646A60DB.description: Analyze situations in which an object moves with specified acceleration under the influence of one or more forces so they can determine the magnitude and direction of the net force, or of one of the forces that makes up the net force, in situations such as the following:

C6F43F6181BD4B29A5661A03A08E2466.description: Determine the components of hte velocity and acceleration vectors at any instant, and sketch or identify graphs of these quantities.

E3DF06A9C8904A50BDE6C5A7454D1DFD.description: Describe the direction of the particle's velocity and acceleration at any instant during the motion.

954192C26FCC4BB0A9CDFE42F4F09B74.description: Relate the radius of the circle and the speed or rate of revolution of the particle to the magnitude of the centripetal acceleration.

8674DC2841284D75A2166ECA7611BDD4.description: Students should understand the uniform circular motion of a particle, so they can:

0F838A87F11E4ACDA7501D004D79B7D8.description: Analyze the motion of particles relative to a frame of reference that is accelerating horizontally or vertically at a uniform rate.

694E03F1655C49618082BA51894868E1.description: Analyze the uniform motion of an object relative to a moving medium such as a flowing stream.

C613558F382445D98AE3C01EE8D1A7E9.description: Students should understand frames of reference, so they can:

044D45C660B74A01830EAA6FC1217FBA.description: Analyze situations in which two or more objects are pushed apart by a spring or other agency, and calculate how much energy is released in such a process.

6D02975D4B374A968B8DCBEB941B6392.description: Apply linear momentum conservation to two-dimensional elastic and inelastic collisions.

00E2A7E37FEF4D93B8B1BD8C65FF27CF.description: Apply linear momentum conservation to one-dimensional elastic and inelastic collisions and two-dimensional completely inelastic collisions.

59B190815C984CD692F361255EDD5EC9.description: Identify situations in which linear momentum, or a component of the linear momentum vector, is conserved.

5E3C64A1E0AE4034B71E847F788B5287.description: Explain how linear momentum conservation follows as a consequence of Newton's third law for an isolated system.

B259A9EF203E4999934412C8023C2C6F.description: Students should understand linear momentum conservation, so they can:

BD0F5001A8F549179B4E43BD2FDAE744.description: Calculate the change in momentum of an object given a function F(t) for the net force acting on the object.

6F3574E83CFD44DD9526BF5BCEF12041.description: Calculate the area under a force versus time graph and relate it to the change in momentum of an object.

5A30908BA7AA4151932091CD7092F327.description: State and apply the relations between linear momentum and center-of-mass motion for a system of particles.

8E2E490C6EF941A1BFB080ED7B71A612.description: Relate impulse to the change in linear momentum and the average force acting on an object.

79B83FBA410448399AFC932E81479D6A.description: Relate mass, velocity, and linear momentum for a moving object, and calculate the total linear momentum for a moving object, and calculate the total linear momentum of a system of objects.

9FBCE2556D74493FA1D24E20FDA8F86A.description: Students should understand impulse and linear momentum, so they can:

80E4D5D0ACB04F7AA89C55BCDA1C48CE.description: Students should be able to define center of gravity and to use this concept to express the gravitational potential energy of a rigid object in terms of the position of its center of mass.

781333B04A904E2EA646E769564419A2.description: Students should be able to understand and apply the relation between center-of-mass velocity and linear momentum, and between center-of-mass acceleration and net external force for a system of particles.

157DBF49359D464C935A945B314C51D6.description: Use integration to find the center of mass of a thin rod of non-uniform density.

7C3A516DBDA64561A589AE6CDA733C29.description: Locate the center of mass of a system consisting of two such objects.

227658B2140A4239864412B894138AD9.description: Identify by inspection the center of mass of a symmetrical object.

BC27AA7360BF4B28AA3254022C0DBDD4.description: Students should understand the technique for finding center of mass , so they can:

059AF5C27B2F4A8E959020067403B07B.description: Calculate the work performed by a force that supplies constant power, or the average power supplied by a  force that performs a specified amount of work.

732D325AC4954658AE861DB9C6C9AD8E.description: Calculate the power required to maintain the motion of an object with constant acceleration (e.g., to move an object along a level surface, to raise an object at a constant rate, or to overcome friction for an object that is moving at a constant speed).

EB1BDA205F7D47A2ACEF1FEBD016D3D7.description: Students should understand the definition fo power, so they can:

1A79263F943D46EA86B493D8E012226F.description: Students should be able to recognize and solve problems that call for application both of conservation of energy and Newton's laws.

BBBE21299FD644BDA72DEE788454428B.description: Apply conservation of energy in analyzing the motion of objects that move under the influence of other non-constant one-dimensional forces.

3D8AD941FC724302968C3E342DCF7223.description: Apply conservation of energy in analyzing the motion of objects that move under the influence of springs

542305CFBE1C4A5DAAA5B255255375D5.description: Apply conservation of energy in analyzing the motion of systems of connected objects, such as an Atwood's machine.

82BC59699C3A41508B472D40EC2FC73F.description: Identify situations in which mechanical energy is or is not conserved.

A924FF78350E4631AACF572EB560B3FE.description: Students should understand conservation of energy, so they can:

65EE61D7E45F41C68884B79B208F65CC.description: Analyze situations in which an object's mechanical energy is changed by friction or by a specified externally applied force.

E337C84DAB45411EBB63D84EB2C38748.description: Describe and identify situation in which mechanical energy is converted to other forms of energy.

3F5332863BA54E74BB18C4BE1D9D520F.description: State and apply the relation between the work performed on an object by non-conservative forces and the change in an object's mechanical energy.

4B34FEEB32D942B888D4D934272A1734.description: Students should understand the concepts of mechanical energy and of total energy, so they can:

8DFE5880B2E94547B08DBBDFF495C902.description: Calculate the potential energy of one or more objects in a uniform gravitational field.

852CC056C3C24CC3A9E48D634FEC0CFB.description: Write an expression for the force exerted by an ideal spring and for the potential energy of a stretched or compressed spring.

8096EFB871704C34B3273966B1079FAF.description: Calculate the magnitude and direction of a one-dimensional force when given the potential energy function U(x) for the force.

754846D5F0764D54B0A0C74411D48CDA.description: Calculate a potential energy function associated with a specified one-dimensional force F(x).

1551E1483CD54BED85C15A27A362C07A.description: State the general relation between force and potential energy, and explain why potential energy can be associated only with conservative forces.

0BDEFA951EA84EFB939FA2C33AE02969.description: Students should understand the concept of potential energy, so they can:

A89C97EE083D4A99B0271A7FBD996364.description: Describe examples of conservative forces and non-conservative forces.

83F042E2C2B74002869992FA04AEB9A0.description: State alternative definitions of "conservative force" and explain why these definitions are equivalent.

227BC88E00B641E79AFC3716E94D599E.description: Students should understand the concept of a conservative force, so they can:

71C671FEBE4843F5B334ACD51CBF1AA8.description: Apply the theorem to determine the change in an object's kinetic energy and speed that result from the application of specified forces, or to determine the force that is required in order to bring an object to rest in a specified distance.

73DD4B7ED68B4D00B62C53DB488773C0.description: Calculate the work performed by the net force, or by each of the forces that make up the net force, on an object that undergoes a specified change in speed or kinetic energy.

01849378E1254E10B2214329D565E84D.description: Calculate the change in kinetic energy or speed that results form performing a specified amount of work on an object.

A2119F2DB982439E8E32F96A95E7EA47.description: Students should understand and be able to apply the work-energy theorem, so they can:

C3D2157DE4BA4659B09295CCCD782D9B.description: Use the scalar product operation to calculate the work performed by a specified constant force F on an object that undergoes a displacement in a plane.

D22C23DF4BF14B25BC8AE213C3601204.description: Use integration to calculate the work performed by a force F(x) on an object that undergoes a specified displacement in one dimension.

B3A6017482454A03AE7AD476AD0E32F7.description: Relate the work done by a force to the area under a graph of force as a function of position, and calculate this work in the case where the force is a linear function of position.

58C3138D901A41F69A54CBC78BE82EEE.description: Calculate the work done by a specified constant force on an object that undergoes a specified displacement.

7033F09084E84124BF046ED17B4E8399.description: Students should understand the definition of work, including when it is positive, negative or zero, so they can:

A63279D64AD04F698663A3B0FE76C821.description: Students should be able to solve problems in which applications of Newton's laws leads to two or three simultaneous linear equations involving unknown forces or accelerations

1B625F087BD94C4BAF11A0F9B5D66CB4.description: Students should know that the tension is constant in a light string that passes over a massless pulley and should be able to use this fact in analyzing the motion of a system of two objects joined by a string.

2998C95283754737BC50B22802CA392C.description: Students should be able to apply Newton's third law in analyzing the force of contact between two objects that accelerate together along a horizontal or vertical line, or between two surfaces that slide across one another.

E2B51553402C4CABB3DCD30300C1D3DC.description: Students should understand Newton's third law so that, for a given system, they can identify the force pairs and the objects on which they act, and state the magnitude and direction of each force.

DCDB1789071A400888A886F365F77CE9.description: Systems of two or more objects (third law)

64A8F39E313246ADBE146FA931CAE226.description: Derive an expression for the acceleration as a function of time for an object falling under the influence of drag forces.

A3508562CE364D6A850262392D8A1C27.description: Use the method of separation of variables to derive the equation for the velocity as a function of time from the differential equation that follows from Newton's second law.

1E9F02A6E9D64129A7F97C540211C8B3.description: Use Newton's second law to write a differential equation for the velocity of the object as a function of time.

25B90E5311D84432B0AE284BD33389F5.description: Describe qualitatively, with the aid of graphs, the acceleration, velocity and displacement of such a particle when it is released from rest or is projected vertically with specified initial velocity

1761B235DF774C06908222907DBC5991.description: Find the terminal velocity of an object moving vertically under the influence of a retarding force dependent on velocity.

1FC9C7FF71A14B60949C8A54F98D9B3B.description: Students should understand the effect of drag forces on the motion of an object, so they can:

4F9254972CEB49DB82784E1FBE8032F2.description: Analyze under what circumstances an object will start to slip, or to calculate the magnitude of the force of static friction.

600FC7D5534D4D8E90ABEF2351CD1E77.description: Analyze situations in which an object moves along a rough inclined plane or horizontal surface.

FD52541AE83E4A3B9C5DC18637D7B51C.description: Write down the relationship between the normal and frictional forces on a surface.

4FB1BBC9BBF347F4B7A9400F010CF626.description: Students should understand the significance of the coefficient of friction, so they can:

E4F21A8359F24615B7D455C7FF443984.description: Students should be able to analyze situations in which an object moves with specified acceleration under the influence of one or more forces so they can determine the magnitude and direction of the net force, or of one of the forces that makes up the net force, such as motion up or down with constant acceleration.

F634DE82D2F1445FA671FF8452F7DF81.description: Write down the vector equations that results from applying Newton's second law to the object, and take components of this equation along appropriate axes.

E86ACCAC146A4F31B124D62D9FBFA319.description: Draw a well-labeled, free-body diagram showing all real forces that act on the object.

6E6FEB93864E441383C3F5A4BC35F7CD.description: Students should understand how Newton's second law, Fnet=ma, applies to an object subject to forces such as gravity, the pull of strings, or contact forces, so they can:

2FD187E8A03F4CF68AAE97E05089F357.description: Determine, for an object moving in a plane whose velocity vector undergoes a specified change over a specified time interval, the average force that acts on the object.

9ED75B49202645C7BD9DA91C1A9D7457.description: Calculate, for an object moving in one dimension, the velocity change that results when a force F(t) acts over a specified time interval.

5B33732340E844088FCF368D5435BB64.description: Calculate, for an object moving in one dimension, the velocity change that results when a constant force F acts over a specified time interval.

48EBAE6C373848308D59891EC46EB7CE.description: Students should understand the relationship between the force that acts on an object and the resulting change in the object's velocity, so they can:

3110429F5D454D8685B37F34C0BAE6E2.description: Dynamics of a single particle (second law)

7DA3CE2AB39B4A2A88A7F311E1D5B702.description: Students should be able to analyze situations in which a particle remains at rest, or moves with constant velocity, under the influence of several forces.

F0CDCB67005547739A799BFF6FA57D3C.description: Use these expressions in analyzing the motion of a projectile that is projected with an arbitrary initial velocity.

A6F86F4E3FEB483E8F86E429BBB954E5.description: Write down expressions for the horizontal and vertical components of velocity and position as functions of time, and sketch or identify graphs of these components.

43D0B296A906435DA8EEFC9E55D40188.description: Students should understand the motion of projectiles in a uniform gravitational field, so they can:

A59184EE3C13400AA32EFD214B4A311C.description: Students should understand the general motion of a particle in two dimensions so that, given functions x(t) and y(t) which describe this motion, they can determine the components, magnitude and direction of the particles velocity and acceleration as functions of time.

4853E467ED4A4010A374F974D47A8B19.description: Determine the change in velocity of a particle or the velocity of one particle relative to another.

FC259DA1FB4542C5AE7856CAE5B4B949.description: Determine the net displacement of a particle or the location of a particle relative to another.

47CBD80E1BF840619ECE55403690D628.description: Determine components of a vector along two specified, mutually perpendicular axes.

98111918F3A74A859B350EF48D2C436C.description: Students should be able to add, subtract and resolve displacement and velocity vectors, so they can:

BC371BBEC3D54509A6EACF61A15CDE17.description: Motion in two dimensions, including projectile motion

AFC6E14C6FF64EF2A02E8DAFAEEA9E43.description: Students should know how to deal with situations in which acceleration is a specified function of velocity and time so they can write an appropriate differential equation and solve it for v(t) by separation of variables, incorporating correctly a given initial value of v.

B8FE8B5CB3B94D97AF37FEA2974940E4.description: Use the equations v = v. + at, x = x. + v.t + 1/2a(t)^2, and v^2 = v.^2 + 2a(x - x.) to solve problems involving one-dimensional motion with constant acceleration (NOTE: the period (.) is a stand-in for subscript 0)

C317617B5B004B88BCAE2BC266AAE6CD.description: Write down expressions for velocity and position as functions of time, and identify or sketch graphs of these quantities.

B5BCAE0590894A979F7151CA94F43B52.description: Students should understand the special case of motion with constant acceleration, so they can:

8FD64CCBB02449D897CC58C3CB8937A8.description: Given an expression for one of the kinematic quantities, position, velocity or acceleration, as a function of time, they can determine the other two as a function of time, and find when they quantities are zero or achieve their maximum and minimum values.

AB256C08B0DA477AB4B10BDFD09EF116.description: Given a graph of one of the kinematic quantities, position, velocity, or acceleration, as a function of time, they can recognize in what time intervals the other two are positive, negative, or zero and can identify or sketch a graph of each as a function of time.

4E7332C1B0DF459390C3DC7F84D761A3.description: Students should understand the general relationships among position, velocity and acceleration for the motion of a particle along a straight line, so that:

FB65590CD2374C1DB881DDDBBA597E0E.description: Kinematics (including vectors, vector algebra, components of vectors, coordinate systems, displacement, velocity and acceleration)
